raw_response:
Here is the structured JSON response based on the extracted information:

```json
{
  "q3_revenue": "180169",
  "q3_operating_income": "17422",
  "q3_diluted_eps": "1.95",
  "q4_revenue_guidance": "206.0 - 213.0",
  "q4_operating_income_guidance": "21.0 - 26.0",
  "summary": "Amazon delivered a robust Q3 2025, with total net sales reaching $180.2 billion, reflecting a 13% year-over-year (Y/Y) growth and a 12% increase on a foreign exchange-neutral basis. Operating income remained flat Y/Y at $17.4 billion, though this includes $4.3 billion in special charges: a $2.5 billion legal settlement with the Federal Trade Commission and $1.8 billion in estimated severance costs. Excluding these charges, operating income would have been $21.7 billion, demonstrating underlying strength in profitability. Diluted earnings per share (EPS) stood at $1.95, up 37% Y/Y, bolstered by pre-tax gains of $9.5 billion from investments in Anthropic, PBC.\n\nSegment performance highlighted divergent trends. North America net sales grew 11% Y/Y to $106.3 billion, though operating income declined 15% to $4.8 billion due to the FTC settlement and severance costs. Excluding these charges, North America operating income would have been $7.3 billion. International net sales rose 14% Y/Y (10% F/X-adjusted) to $40.9 billion, while operating income decreased 8% Y/Y to $1.2 billion, impacted by severance costs and increased shipping expenses. AWS continued its strong performance, with net sales up 20% Y/Y to $33.0 billion and operating income increasing 9% Y/Y to $11.4 billion, driven by higher customer usage and strategic investments in technology infrastructure.\n\nAmazon provided Q4 2025 guidance anticipating net sales between $206.0 billion and $213.0 billion, representing 10-13% Y/Y growth, and operating income between $21.0 billion and $26.0 billion. This guidance reflects confidence in continued momentum, though it assumes no additional business acquisitions, restructurings, or legal settlements. Management emphasized strategic initiatives, including expansions in AI-powered devices, cloud services, and autonomous technologies like Zoox’s robotaxi service. The company also announced a $1 billion investment in U.S. employee pay and benefits, raising the average hourly wage to over $30, alongside a $2.5 billion commitment to workforce education and training through the Future Ready 2030 initiative. These investments underscore Amazon’s focus on long-term growth, operational efficiency, and talent development amid a dynamic macroeconomic environment."
}
```

parsed_response.summary:
Amazon delivered a robust Q3 2025, with total net sales reaching $180.2 billion, reflecting a 13% year-over-year (Y/Y) growth and a 12% increase on a foreign exchange-neutral basis. Operating income remained flat Y/Y at $17.4 billion, though this includes $4.3 billion in special charges: a $2.5 billion legal settlement with the Federal Trade Commission and $1.8 billion in estimated severance costs. Excluding these charges, operating income would have been $21.7 billion, demonstrating underlying strength in profitability. Diluted earnings per share (EPS) stood at $1.95, up 37% Y/Y, bolstered by pre-tax gains of $9.5 billion from investments in Anthropic, PBC.

Segment performance highlighted divergent trends. North America net sales grew 11% Y/Y to $106.3 billion, though operating income declined 15% to $4.8 billion due to the FTC settlement and severance costs. Excluding these charges, North America operating income would have been $7.3 billion. International net sales rose 14% Y/Y (10% F/X-adjusted) to $40.9 billion, while operating income decreased 8% Y/Y to $1.2 billion, impacted by severance costs and increased shipping expenses. AWS continued its strong performance, with net sales up 20% Y/Y to $33.0 billion and operating income increasing 9% Y/Y to $11.4 billion, driven by higher customer usage and strategic investments in technology infrastructure.

Amazon provided Q4 2025 guidance anticipating net sales between $206.0 billion and $213.0 billion, representing 10-13% Y/Y growth, and operating income between $21.0 billion and $26.0 billion. This guidance reflects confidence in continued momentum, though it assumes no additional business acquisitions, restructurings, or legal settlements. Management emphasized strategic initiatives, including expansions in AI-powered devices, cloud services, and autonomous technologies like Zoox’s robotaxi service. The company also announced a $1 billion investment in U.S. employee pay and benefits, raising the average hourly wage to over $30, alongside a $2.5 billion commitment to workforce education and training through the Future Ready 2030 initiative. These investments underscore Amazon’s focus on long-term growth, operational efficiency, and talent development amid a dynamic macroeconomic environment.
